awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Long Term Maintenance of Sustainable Agriculture
awd_abstract_narration:
Establishing sustainable and productive agricultural systems is increasingly important as global population growth and climatic instability pose new challenges to food security. However, the centuries- or millennia-long time scales necessary to evaluate true long-term sustainability are often inaccessible through contemporary ecological datasets. The deep-time cultural and environmental datasets analyzed by archaeologists therefore offer a unique window into understanding sustainable agricultural practices across millennia, allowing researchers insight into both the social and environmental factors that contribute to (or inhibit) the longevity of productive agro-ecosystems systems. This project will apply a multidisciplinary archaeological and ecological approach to investigate 800+ years of indigenous agricultural activities in a windward Hawaiian Valley (Halāwa Valley, Moloka‘i Island) and evaluate its long-term productivity and sustainability. It will provide new insight into the establishment and growth of intensive agricultural systems, including the impacts of agriculture on local soils, water use, and vegetation, as well as the ways past people adapted to climatic fluctuations and resource limitations. As a community-based participatory research project, researchers will work in collaboration with local community members and non-profit organizations to facilitate archaeology and heritage management training opportunities for local stakeholders, and to apply research results towards ecosystem restoration and sustainable agriculture on Moloka‘i. This research will also offer STEM training opportunities for Native Hawaiians and other underrepresented stakeholders in field, laboratory, and museum settings. 

This project will combine re-analysis of previously excavated archaeological collections with renewed field survey and excavations in Halāwa Valley to test the hypothesis that intensive wet-valley Hawaiian agro-ecosystems were not only highly productive, but sustainable across centuries of agricultural activities. This research will address six primary objectives: (1) archaeological survey and mapping, targeted excavation, and new high-precision radiocarbon dating will be applied to document the development of irrigated agriculture and water flow control mechanisms. (2) GIS mapping, soil, and microbotanical analyses will be applied to investigate the nature and extent of colluvial slope agriculture within the valley, an under-researched but likely critical component of food production in Halāwa Valley. (3) Chemical analyses of soil samples will characterize soil fertility across the valley and examine the impacts of centuries of agriculture on soil nutrient availability. (4) Analysis of archival records will investigate early post-contact land use and water rights to characterize the past social and political context of agricultural systems in Halāwa. (5) Analysis of archaeological faunal remains will examine the development of animal husbandry and its integration into food production and resource allocation decisions. Stable isotope analysis of pig, dog, and rat remains will examine changes to food webs and nutrient flows across agro-ecosystems to evaluate changing land use and sustainability. (6) Limited test excavations at Hawaiian agricultural temple (heiau) sites will provide a chronological sequence for sociopolitical developments in the valley linked to agricultural intensification and productivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project has been to apply a multi-disciplinary approach--with archaeology as the core integrating discipline--to a case study of traditional Hawaiian windward or wet valley agriculture, often claimed to be an example of sustainable production based on indigenous farming methods.  Centered on the irrigated cultivation of taro (Colocasia esculenta) combined with mixed cropping on colluvial slopes, such farming systems provided the basis for the traditional economies on the geologically-older islands from west Maui, through Moloka'i and O'ahu, to Kaua'i. Focusing on the case study of Hālawa Valley, Moloka'i, we have traced the development over time of three essential components of (1) irrigation, (2) colluvial slope horticulture and agro-forestry, and (3) domestic animal husbandry, determining how this multi-component system was constrained by and mapped onto the underlying environmental mosaic of soils, streams, and rainfall.

 We investigated the temporal development and dynamics of intensive pondfield agriculture in Hālawa Valley at selected sites that represent the range of irrigation techniques from small-scale, tributary-stream watered terraces up to the largest alluvial-floodplain field complexes. Detailed mapping of terraces, canals, and other features within these systems provided data on water flow and control. We archaeologically excavated trenches to expose construction sequences for both pondfields and dryland (colluvial slope) terraces. Radiocarbon dating of 50 samples (either charcoal or non-carbonized candlenut nutshell) obtained through these excavations has allowed the establishment of a chronology for the development of the irrigation systems. We also sampled the stratified pondfield soil sequences within irrigated terraces and analysed these for essential plant nutrient properties such as Carbon and Phosphorus, and for base saturation in order to determine whether there were significant changes in pondfield soil nutrients over time, as part of our goal of objectively measuring long-term sustainability. Preliminary results suggest that Phosphorus does decline in pondfield soils after long periods of continuous cultivation.

 Our studies of both main-stream irrigated and tributary-stream irrigated complexes in Hālawa Valley have allowed us to infer a more refined chronology for the development of the valley?s irrigation infrastructure. The earliest known pondfields date to the fourteenth century, and are situated near the head of the large main-stream irrigated lower valley irrigation complex. The upper irrigation canal (?auwai) of this complex was in use by at least the fifteenth century, if not earlier. In contrast, the large pondfields of this complex situated on the lower valley floodplain were not developed until around the eighteenth century. Thus, it appears that the extensive lower valley, main-stream irrigation system developed gradually over time from the highest (most inland) terraces down to the coastal floodplain. Sediment eroded from the inland slopes due to forest clearance and cultivation was carried downstream and with periodic over-bank flooding stabilized the lower floodplain sufficiently for pondfields to be developed there in late pre-contact times.

The tributary-stream irrigation complexes in the middle valley have been shown to be developments of the late pre-contact period, in the seventeenth to eighteenth centuries. Using a form of hydraulic engineering, these small terraces were constructed on colluvial fan deposits adjacent to the tributary streams, by sluicing in stream sediments to fill in behind the constructed stone retaining walls. Development of irrigation infrastructure in Kapana continued into the early post-contact period with the construction of the massive main-stream irrigated terraces that partly buried the lower tributary-stream terraces irrigated by Maka?ele?ele Stream. This last phase of construction was likely facilitated by the use of iron tools.

Applying a multi-disciplinary and multi-proxy approach with archaeology as the core integrating discipline, we investigated the hypothesis that traditional wet-valley Hawaiian agro-ecosystems were not only highly productive but also sustainable on a centuries-long time scale. We refined a chronological sequence of agricultural development within the Hālawa Valley, including its key subsystems of main-stream irrigation, tributary-stream irrigation, colluvial slope cultivation (and agro-forestry), and domestic animal husbandry, and achieved a detailed understanding of how these subsystems were integrated in a broader social and political context (i.e., the socio-ecosystem). We have also achieved a more detailed understanding of soil variability throughout this representative ?wet? valley, and how this variability contributed to the high level of traditional agricultural production. Addressing the sustainability question objectively remains challenging, but our initial analysis of soil nutrients in the irrigation systems points to long-term drawdowns in key nutrients such as Phosphorus. Stable isotope analysis of the faunal remains from the Hālawa Dune Site, still in progress, should help to clarify the question of nutrient flows over time. In addition to its substantive contribution to Hawaiian and Polynesian archaeology and prehistory, our project has generated deep-time understandings of human influence on agricultural -ecosystems, as well as new high-resolution paleoenvironmental data for agricultural strategies that have received minimal archaeological attention (particularly colluvial slope agriculture and intensive animal husbandry). These data have implications for restoration and conservation, and are relevant questions of global sustainability.
